What is your overall assessment of this course?

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You will learn a lot about the methods used in sociology! This class definitely does what it is intended to do, and you'll walk out with feasible approaches to conducting research.
Qualitative and quantitative sociological research methods and when they should/should not be used. Practice using surveys and interviews.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is generally very small, which was really nice as it made class feel almost like office hours. I thought the readings selected were great and offered a lot of exposure to different methods. Another major strength is professor Menon. She is always able to break things down in a way that makes themes or methods really digestible and accessible. She is also just really approachable, accomplished, and cool. Her recorded lectures are super well organized and contain really great information, and having the recorded lectures meant that we spent most of our class time discussing, which was great. One small weakness was that sometimes methods are not the most exciting thing to talk about so, at points, discussion felt a bit dry. But this has nothing to do with Menon or the format, I think it's just the nature of a methods class.
Professor Menon chooses great readings and the mini-lectures really support learning that happens during class time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures were definitely a success. They were short but very engaging and informational. I wish it had been a requirement to have cameras on in this class. There were times when only one or two people did even though it was a seminar.
I really liked the mini-lectures, not too sure if those are used outside of virtual learning but I thought they were helpful!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YIf you are a sociology major or you are at all interested in conducting research at any point, absolutely take this class. Even if you have research experience, you will learn so much, and Menon is great.
Yes. This class teaches a valuable skill set and approach to research

Absolutely!! Professor Menon is great. It does not go in-depth into all of the methods but gives a really good idea of when different research methods should be used. Helpful even non-sociology majors who want an introduction to research methods.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class consisted of prerecorded lectures, virtual seminar discussions, and occasional live lectures.
